item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Suggested text: Our website address is: http://mxp4295.uta.cloud/blog.

Comments

Suggested text: When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

Suggested text: If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Cookies

Suggested text: If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Suggested text: Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Who we share your data with

Suggested text: If you request a password reset, your IP address will be included in the reset email.

How long we retain your data

Suggested text: If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

Suggested text: If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where your data is sent

Suggested text: Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

item.title: About Margarita
item.dc:creator: root
item.content:encoded:
Margarita is beautiful island. It is located in south America. It has beautiful mountains in south. Most of the city life is located in west side of the island. It famous for incredible food dishes.

Margarita was discovered by Columbus in 1498 and quickly became known for its pearls. Through the centuries, settlements on the island were besieged by Indians (in reprisal for slave raids on the mainland) and by British pirates and Dutch forces. Its traders rendered invaluable assistance to the revolutionists in the struggle for independence from Spain. Simon Bolivar used the island as a base of operations in 1816, and the Spanish general Pablo Morillo was driven from its shores in 1817.

Until the early 20th century, the population of Margarita was predominantly indigenous, with some Spanish ancestry traceable mainly to the Canary Islands. Since 1920 the island has attracted immigrants from abroad, but at the same time many islanders have migrated to the mainland in search of more favourable employment. Farming and grazing are carried on, but the island is a net importer of foodstuffs. The pearl industry is still important; fishing, the building of fishing boats, tourism (especially since World War II), and the manufacture of tile, ceramics, shoes, hats, and salt are additional sources of income. Although the capital is La Asuncion , the most important city is Porlamar, which is the centre of the pearl industry and has an airport. A major boom in construction, tourism has occurred since Porlamar was declared a duty-free port in the 1970s. The islandâ€™s largest port is at Pampatar.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I wish to visit Margarita Island one day.
I too have added this island to my bucket list.

item.title: Yogesh
item.dc:creator: Yogesh
item.content:encoded:
Hellooo Visiters....

I am Yogesh Mudaliyar. I am from India. I am doing my Master in UTA. This is my 3rd Semester. I am doing my master in computer science. I have great experience in IT industry.

My favorite thing about Margarita is nature and food. It has so many beautiful places to visit. When I was in my 8th standard, I have visited this Island for the first time with my parents.

This are some picture, which I have capture during my vacation on this island.

This was my hotel room view. It is one of the beautiful mountain. I went fro hiking over there. I have also made some friend over there. I eat some local food as well.

item.title: Krupa
item.dc:creator: Krupa
item.content:encoded:
Hello Everyone...
I am Krupa. I am from Gujarat. I have done my graduation from VGEC. Currently, I am doing my masters from UTA. This is my last semester. I went Margarita last summer for vacation with my roommates. It is beautiful place. tâ€™s a popular holiday destination, comprising 2 peninsulas linked by the sand and mangroves of the Laguna de la Restinga national park. Most people live, or stay, on the eastern peninsula, home to the cities of Pampatar, Porlamar and La Asuncion.
Margarita is beautiful island. It is located in south America. It has beautiful mountains in south. Most of the city life is located in west side of the island. It famous for incredible food dishes.Margarita Island, home of the best margaritas in New York City! Serving a variety of bites to snack on while enjoying the sun and music.Lying in a fertile inland valley in the eastern portion of the island, La AsunciÃ³n was first settled by Spaniards in 1524. Its inland location provided some protection from pirate attacks.
Isla de Margarita was discovered by Columbus in 1498 and quickly became known for its pearls. Through the centuries, settlements on the island were besieged by Indians (in reprisal for slave raids on the mainland) and by British pirates and Dutch forces. Languorously lounging around at a white sand beach, sipping on chilled margaritas captures the perfect summer holiday at an island.

item.title: About Beach
item.dc:creator: Mansi
item.content:encoded:
AÂ beachÂ is a narrow, gently sloping strip of land that lies along the edge of an ocean, lake, or river. Materials such asÂ sand,Â pebbles, rocks, and seashellÂ fragmentsÂ coverÂ beaches.

MostÂ beachÂ materials are the products ofÂ weatheringÂ andÂ erosion. Over many years, water and wind wear away at the land. The continual action of waves beating against a rockyÂ cliff, for example, may cause some rocks to come loose. Huge boulders can be worn town to tiny grains ofÂ sand.

BeachÂ materials may travel long distances, carried by wind and waves. As theÂ tideÂ comes in, for example, it deposits oceanÂ sediment. ThisÂ sedimentÂ may containÂ sand, shells, seaweed, even marineÂ organismsÂ like crabs or sea anemones. When theÂ tideÂ goes out, it takes someÂ sedimentÂ with it.

TidesÂ and oceanÂ currentsÂ can carryÂ sedimentÂ a few meters or hundreds of kilometers away.Â TidesÂ andÂ currentsÂ are the main wayÂ beachesÂ are created, changed, and even destroyed, as theÂ currentsÂ moveÂ sedimentÂ andÂ debrisÂ from one place to another.

BeachesÂ are constantly changing.Â TidesÂ and weather can alterÂ beachesÂ every day, bringing new materials and taking away others.

BeachesÂ also change seasonally. During the winter, storm winds tossÂ sandÂ into the air. This can sometimes erodeÂ beachesÂ and createÂ sandbars.Â SandbarsÂ are narrow, exposed areas ofÂ sandandÂ sedimentÂ just off theÂ beach. During the summer, waves retrieveÂ sandÂ fromÂ sandbarsÂ and build theÂ beachÂ back up again. These seasonal changes causeÂ beachesÂ to be wider and have a gentle slope in the summer, and be narrower and steeper in the winter.

Beach Berms

EveryÂ beachÂ has aÂ beach profile. AÂ beachÂ profileÂ describes theÂ landscapeÂ of theÂ beach, both above the water and below it.Â BeachesÂ can be warm, and rich inÂ vegetationÂ such as palm or mangrove trees.Â BeachesÂ can also be barren desert coastlines. OtherÂ beachesÂ are cold and rocky, whileÂ beachesÂ in the Arctic and Antarctic are frozen almost all year.

The area above the water, including theÂ intertidal zone, is known as theÂ beachÂ berm.Â BeachÂ bermÂ can includeÂ vegetation, such as trees, shrubs, or grasses. The most familiarÂ characteristicÂ of aÂ beachÂ bermÂ is its type ofÂ sandÂ or rock.

Sandy
MostÂ beachÂ sandÂ comes from several different sources. SomeÂ sandÂ may be eroded bits of a rockyÂ reefÂ just offshore. Others may be eroded rock from nearbyÂ cliffs. PensacolaÂ Beach, in the U.S. state of Florida, for instance, has white,Â sandyÂ beaches. SomeÂ sandÂ is eroded from rocks andÂ mineralsÂ in the Gulf of Mexico. MostÂ sand, however, is made of tinyÂ particlesÂ of weathered quartz from the Appalachian Mountains, hundreds of kilometers away.

TheÂ sandyÂ beachesÂ surrounding Chameis Bay, Namibia, are also full of quartz and seashells. However, theÂ beachesÂ of Chameis Bay contain another type of rockâ€”diamonds.Â MiningÂ companies have dug mines both on theÂ beachÂ and offshore toÂ excavatethese precious stones. OtherÂ gems, such as sapphires, emeralds, and garnets, are present on manyÂ beachesÂ throughout the world, as tiny grains ofÂ sand.

Rocky
SomeÂ beachÂ bermsÂ are notÂ sandyÂ at all. They are covered with flatÂ pebblesÂ calledÂ shinglesÂ or rounded rocks known asÂ cobbles. SuchÂ beachesÂ are common along the coasts of the British Isles. HastingsÂ Beach, aÂ shingleÂ beachÂ on the southern coast of England, has been a dock for fishing boats for more than a thousandÂ years.

A stormÂ beachÂ is a type ofÂ shingleÂ beachÂ that is often hit by heavy storms. Strong waves and winds batter stormÂ beachesinto narrow, steep landforms. TheÂ shinglesÂ on stormÂ beachesÂ are usually small near the water and large at the highest elevation.
SomeÂ beaches, calledÂ barrier beaches, protect the mainland from the battering of ocean waves. TheseÂ beachesÂ may lie at the heads of islands called barrier islands. ManyÂ barrierÂ beachesÂ and barrier islands stretch along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts of the United States. These narrowÂ beachesÂ form barriers between the open ocean and protected harbors, lagoons, and sounds.

BeachesÂ near rivers are often muddy or soft.Â SoilÂ andÂ sedimentfrom the river is carried to the riverâ€™sÂ mouth, sometimes creating aÂ fertileÂ beach. Hoi An, Vietnam, is an ancient town that sits on the estuary of the Thu Bon River and the South China Sea. Hoi Anâ€™s softÂ beachesÂ serve asÂ resortÂ and tourist center.

BeachÂ bermsÂ can be many different colors.Â CoralÂ beaches, common on islands in the Caribbean Sea, are white and powdery. They are made from the erodedÂ exoskeletonsÂ of tiny animals calledÂ corals. SomeÂ coralÂ beaches, such as Harbour Island, Bahamas, actually have pinkÂ sand. TheÂ coralÂ that created theseÂ beachesÂ were pink or red.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This post about beach is so much informative.
